elements.name: explanationIntro
elements.title: First, we are asking about the person who died. All the questions revolve around them. We will ask about you, the applicant(s), in a later step.

elements.name: deceasedName
elements.title: What is the name of the person who died?
elements.description:
This is the name you want to appear on the final representation grant given by the Supreme Court of British Columbia.

Is the death certificate the right name to have here as the "legal name"? No. Depends on how the person inputed the name.If it is, is the format on the death certificate the same as First, Middle, Last?

elements.name: deceasedNameFAQ1
elements.title: What if {deceasedName} has more than one middle name?
elements.body: Write all the middle names in on one line and add a space between each middle name.

elements.name: deceasedNameFAQ2
elements.title: What if {deceasedName}'s name is originally in a different language?
elements.body: You will need to provide the English translation of the deceased's name. The Supreme Court of British Columbia requires that all forms are completed in the English language.

elements.name: deceasedNameFAQ3
elements.title: What if {deceasedName} used more than one version of their name?
elements.body: This service will ask you, in future questions, for any additional names. This includes any different spellings that the deceased would have used, such as leaving out any of their middle names.

elements.name: deceasedDateOfDeath
elements.title: What is the date of death as it appears on {deceasedName}'s death certificate?

elements.name: deceasedAddress
elements.title: Where did {deceasedName} live?
elements.description: Enter the address where Deceased Name spent the majority of their time.

elements.name: deceasedAddressFAQ1
elements.title: What if {deceasedName} was homeless?
elements.body: If {deceasedName} was homeless, write "no fixed address" for the street number and street name.

elements.name: firstNations

elements.name: will
elements.title: Did {deceasedName} leave a will?

elements.name: willFAQ1
elements.title: How do I check for a will?
elements.body:
You should start by checking in places where the deceased usually kept their documents. You may not find their will but you may find clues to where the will is kept. The will may be at a variety of places, including the deceased's home, their safety deposit box, or at the office of the lawyer who helped create the will.

As part of applying for a Representation Grant, you will be required to do a "Search of Wills Notice" and provide the results to the court. This is done through the Vital Statistics Agency of British Columbia. If a will was registered with the Vital Statistics Agency, they will have information about the location of the will, but not the actual will itself.

The "Search of Wills Notice" must include a search of all of the different names and spellings that the deceased used in their will and for their assets. If you need help identifying all of the different names and spellings of the deceased, this service will guide you through that process in a later stage.

templateElements.title: Full name of {panel.spouseName}'s committee

templateElements.name: spouseDied5DaysAfter
templateElements.title: Did  die after (Deceased Date of Death + 4 days)?

templateElements.name: spouseDied5DaysAfterFAQ1
templateElements.title: Why does this date matter?
templateElements.body:
In determining who gets part of estate, it is important to know who died first. This may not sound strange, but under the law, if they died less than 5 days after Deceased Name, they are considered to have died before Deceased Name. For more information, refer to Five-day survival rule from the Wills, Estate and Succession Act (WESA).
http://www.bclaws.ca/civix/document/id/complete/statreg/00_09013_01#section10
